Planning for disasters
By Aeleen Frisch

We all know that systems need to be backed up in case of a failure. But
what we sometimes forget is that an effective backup plan is an ongoing
process. This set of questions from Aeleen Frisch's Essential System
Administration will help you design an effective backup plan.

There are many factors to consider in developing a backup plan. These
questions are among the most important:

* What files need to be backed up? The simplest answer is, of course,
everything, and while everything but scratch files and directories need
to be saved somewhere, it doesn't all have to be saved as part of the
system backups. The OS, for example, came on CD-ROM.

* Where are these files? This question involves both where the
important files are with the file system of any particular system and
which systems hold the most important data.

* Who will back up the files? The answer may depend on where the files
are. For example, many sites assign the backup responsibility for
server systems to the system administrator and the individual
workstations up to users. This may or may not be a good idea depending
on whether or not the important files are really being backed up.

* Where, when, and under what conditions should backups be performed?
Where refers to the computer system on which the backup will he
performed; this need not necessarily be the same as the system where
the files are physically located. Similarly, in an ideal world, all
backups would be performed after hours on unmounted file systems.
That's not always practical in the real world, however.

* How often do these files change? This information will help you
decide both when and how often to perform backups and the type of
schedule to implement. For example, if your system supports a large
ongoing development project, then the files on it are likely to change
very frequently and will need to be backed up at least daily and
probably after hours. On the other hand, if the only volatile file on
your system is a large database, its file system might need to be
backed up several times every day while the other file systems on the
same system would be backed up only once a week.

* How quickly does an important missing or damaged file need to be
restored? Backups protect against both widespread and isolated file
loss, and the timeframe in which the key files need to be back on-line
needs to be taken into account. The number of key files, how widely
spread they are throughout a file system (or network), and how large
they are will also influence matters. Your system may have only one
irreplaceable file, but you'll need to plan very differently depending
on whether it is 1K or 1GB in size. (Note that losing even a single 1K
file can wreak havoc if it's the license file without which the central
application program won't run.)

* Where will the data be restored? Will the backup files be used only
on the system from which they were made, or is there an expectation
that they could be restored to a different system in an emergency. If
multisystem compatibility is important some or all of the time, it
needs to be taken into account in designing the backup and recovery
plan.
